title: Quiz 6: Evaluation of Student Performance
topicName: Health Education Unit Five: Teaching and Learning Methodologies
description: Assess your understanding of evaluation concepts, types of evaluation (formative vs. summative), and assessment tools.

questions.question: What is the distinction between 'Assessment' and 'Evaluation'?

options.text: They mean exactly the same thing
Assessment measures the extent of learning; Evaluation places a value on that performance to make a decision
Evaluation is only for teachers; Assessment is for students
Assessment is done at the end; Evaluation is continuous

questions.explanation: Assessment is the measurement (gathering data), while Evaluation is the judgment/decision making based on that data.

questions.question: Match the type of evaluation with its description:

pairs.right: Continuous, diagnostic, provides feedback during learning
Terminal, certifies achievement at the end of a course
Determines entry behaviour before instruction begins

questions.explanation: Formative = During; Summative = End; Placement = Start; Diagnostic = Problem finding.

questions.question: Which of the following are reasons for evaluating learners? (Select all that apply)

options.text: To protect society from incompetent practitioners

questions.explanation: Evaluation serves many positive purposes: motivation, feedback, quality control, certification, and public protection.

questions.question: The acronym 'OSCE' stands for Objective Structured ___BLANK___ Examination, while 'OSPE' stands for Objective Structured ___BLANK___ Examination.
questions.hint: One is for the ward (C), one is for the lab (P).

questions.question: In Multiple Choice Questions (MCQs), what are the incorrect options called?
questions.explanation: The wrong answers are designed to 'distract' students who do not know the material.

questions.question: When marking essays, 'Analytical Scoring' relies on the teacher's general feeling or impression of the answer's quality.
questions.explanation: This describes 'Impression Scoring'. Analytical scoring uses a specific marking scheme/checklist of points to look for.
questions.hint: Analysis implies detail, not just a feeling.

questions.question: Order the steps for developing a valid assessment tool:

items.text: List the objectives to be evaluated
Specify the tools of assessment (e.g., MCQ, Essay)
Allocate marks and develop a marking scheme
Arrange questions in the final paper

questions.explanation: Objectives -> Tool Selection -> Marking Scheme -> Question Writing -> Arrangement.
questions.hint: What do you want to test? How? How much is it worth? Write it.

questions.question: Which of the following is a rule for writing good Multiple Choice Questions?

options.text: Make the correct answer obviously longer than the others
Use ridiculous options to make it easy
Ensure the stem (question) presents a clear problem
Always use 'All of the above' as the answer

questions.explanation: A good MCQ stem should clearly state the problem. Distracters should be plausible, and length should not be a clue.
questions.hint: The question itself must be clear.

questions.question: What type of scale is used to assess attitudes by asking students to tick between opposite characteristics (e.g., Polite ....... Rude)?
questions.explanation: A semantic differential scale measures attitudes using bipolar adjectives (opposites).

questions.question: Which assessment method involves a student rotating through several stations to perform specific tasks within a set time?

richContent.content:
Scenario:
Station 1: Take BP (5 min)
Station 2: Identify Instrument (5 min)
Station 3: Counsel Patient (5 min)

questions.explanation: This 'stations' format is the hallmark of Objective Structured Clinical/Practical Examinations (OSCE/OSPE).
